thread.title: Stephen Colbert Late Show video: Host shines on debut | Jeb Bush interview |
thread.title_full: Stephen Colbert Late Show video: Host shines on debut | Jeb Bush interview | The Advertiser

author: Robert Rorke
title: Stephen Colbert Late Show video: Host shines on debut | Jeb Bush interview |
text:
THE cranky, jaded ghost of David Letterman was driven out of the Ed Sullivan Theatre as its new tenant, Stephen Colbert, made a rousing, late-night debut Tuesday night.
The show kicked off with a pre-taped segment that featured Colbert and various singers in spots around the country singing The Star-Spangled Banner , his way of greeting the country that may not have seen him on The Colbert Report . The segment ended perfectly with former Daily Show host and Colbert mentor Jon Stewart ripping off a catcher’s mask, turning to the crowd to say, “Let’s play ball.”
Colbert could not have asked for a warmer reception from the audience, which chanted his crowd name, “Ste-phen, Ste-phen,” and greeted him with a standing ovation. One had the sense that they had been waiting a long time — nine months, in fact — for this party to get started.
Colbert’s energy was terrific. He did high kicks with his bandleader Jon Batiste and traded jokes with CBS CEO Les Moonves, who had a front-row seat with a buzzer that let him switch Colbert off for re-runs of The Mentalist , the show that occupied the timeslot after Letterman went off the air.
Moonves is, of course, expecting Colbert to be a competitor to frontrunner Jimmy Fallon, whose Tonight Show is a proven success. His jokes were hit and miss. An involved joke about a cursed ram’s head bearing a red amulet simply did not register.
He did better with an extended funny bit about Donald Trump’s complaint that Nabisco is going to make its cookies in Mexico, eating Oreos at his desk while showing video of Trump bloviating at various campaign stops. When Colbert delivers lines like “He’s the only candidate brave enough to deport the Keebler elves,” he lives up to his reputation as the smartest guy in the late-night game. George Clooney departs the first taping of The Late Show With Stephen Colbert on September 8. Source: Getty Images
The interview segments seemed slow in coming, though, and the first, with a goateed George Clooney, could have been sharper, as he and Colbert did a spoof of the standard, self-promoting celebrity interview. Without anything to promote, Clooney was just there to be nice and put Colbert at ease. Colbert had some fun teasing Clooney about him being arm candy for his wife, the accomplished Amal Clooney.
Colbert really hit his stride, though, during an interview with presidential candidate Jeb Bush, asking him substantive questions about changing the country’s political narrative and how he was different from his brother George. Bush tried for some humour here, saying he was younger and better-looking, but Colbert said, “I’m talking policy.” And then Bush rather frankly admitted that his brother the president didn’t show enough fiscal restraint.
Switching gears again, Colbert turned the last segment of his debut night over to Jon Batiste and Stay Human, his band, which delivered an amazing version of the Sly and the Family Stone classic Everyday People , with a special cameo from the mighty Mavis Staples. Proving he’s game for almost anything, Colbert joined the chorus and closed out his debut on a well-deserved high note.
Fans line up for the first taping of The Late Show With Stephen Colbert on September 8 in NYC. Source: Getty Images
This article first appeared on the New York Post.
 Stephen Colbert nails Late Show debut
